titleStmt.author: Kellogg, Ezekiel, 1732-1785.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 27 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 17 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: A poem, on the unsuccessful measures, taken ay [sic] the British Army; in order to enslave and destroy the United States in North-America: from the beginning of the war, 1775, to the taking of General Burgoyne, and the the [sic] army under his command, at Syratoga, 1777.

notesStmt.note: The letter A appears at head of title, perhaps mistakenly repeating the initial article of the title.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2009-03 SPi Global (Manila)Keyed and coded from Readex/Newsbank page images
2010-04 Olivia BottumText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p:
A POEM, ON THE UNSUCCESSFUL MEASURES. TAKEN BY THE BRITISH ARMY; In order to Enſlave and Deſtroy the UNITED STATE •
〈◊〉 North-America: From the Beginning of the War, 〈…〉 the taking of General BURGOYNE and the the Army under his command 〈…〉

lg.l: The great ſalvation of our God
God is a refuge for his ſaints
He hears them when they pray.
How vaſt is that Almighty pow'r
That rools the wheels of providence
When tyrants riſe to vex his ſaints
He makes their own devices prove
Proud Haman muſt be hang'd upon
And Burgoyne fell into the ſnare
That his own hands had ſpread.
Had •• r • d againſt her young as th ••
To make his finger prove more thick
Had George the third example took
Had ſerv'd him, one and all.
I will proceed firſtly to •• d
Tell how the knave tho't to enſlave
In order to lay down my plan
Tell how he chang'd the parliament,
When firſt the act came here;
From one they lov'd ſo dear.
It threw this vaſt great continent
To heav'n they ſend their timely calls
Her ſtrength at that time being ſmall,
The Lord of glory heard her call,
A conſtant peace with good increaſe
God for a time from us conceals
For ſhe no longer muſt enjoy
She muſt be wea •• d, not ſuch the breaſt
And doom'd to be her mother's ſlave
Down to the end of Time.
In order to effect their plan
As Solomon ſays o • a fool,
They tho't if they block'd Boſton in,
And ſo • cely ga • e them breath,
That all this vaſt great continent
Would near be ſ • ar'd to death.
Now having well block • d Boſton in,
The next ſent out to Lexington,
And thurſting much for human blood,
'Twas there they ſhed the blood of war,
All in the time of peace.
The God to whom reveng • elongs,
As you may now well think,
Tho't it high time for this great crime
To give them blood to drink.
And while they boaſt of what they'd done
The neighbouring towns repair to arms,
By this time they rack all their wits
To gain a ſ •• e e •• eat,
But ev'ry where that they repair,
Many are ſl •• n on the retreat,
Others are wounded on the way,
Perhaps they had not yet fill'd up
They blook'd themſelves in Boſton ſafe.
And ſcape the vengeance due to them,
For blood that they had ſhed.
And having paid the price of blood,
Al tho' they had a victory,
But yet near fifteen hundred men
Now near that number they have left
For murd'rers always muſt pay dear
For what their hands have done.
And pay'd the price ſo dear,
That ſo in Boſton they might find
That ſuch as ſhed the blood of man,
Might flee and might not die.
'Twas there they hop'd for quiet reſt,
The wicked's triump • is but ſhort.
They're always like the troubled ſea,
For while they truſt an arm of fleſh,
They are but like great Babylon,
Whoſe plagues come in an hour.
And now we ſee the wicked flee
But muſt they leave their pleaſant home
Be carried to a foreign land
To ſee their friends no more.
How are theſe wretches thunder ſtruck,
Their hearts pierc'd to the centre;
Now for the future let them pray
Their flight be not in winter.
But wo to them that are with child,
And ſuch as do give ſuck;
For how can they poor helpleſs ſouls
And now to ſave a wretched life
Stow'd in a ſhip heaps upon heaps,
God grant they may while on the way,
Should I perſue theſe wretches ſtill
And tire the patience of all thoſe
That read or hear my ſong.
After a dark and ſtormy day,
Sometimes a beam of ſhinning rays,
The God of armies on our ſide,
Exerts his power on our behalf,
But oh! the wretched fruits of pride,
We tho't our hand, and not the Lord's,
We did not render to his name
God ſhews an ang • y countenance,
Britain, with all their foreign pow'rs
The Heſſian or the German troops,
But while that they are gathering here,
Hopeing to make that country feel
We ſent ſome troops to their relief,
And now once more the Britiſh troops
They fall a pray like helpleſs ſheep,
Lord when I do of judgment ſing▪
For to thy name, thou ſov'reign king,

Now Britiſh troops they have perſ •••• ' •
▪
And if it has not made them rich,
I leave them in thei • ſhatter'd ſhips
Who ſaid he came to pardon •• ns,
Now Britiſh ſhips laden with troops,
As clouds that • ather th • ck and •••• k,
This is an awful fight indeed,
This day is great, big with the fate;
By this time they do plainly fee,
Their all does lie at ſtake.
But Oh! that Aaron would (as when,
Methinks our troops they have this day
An awful ſlaughter on both ſides,
And they evacuate the p • ace
And now it ſeems the Britiſh troops
For ſoon we hear that they have got
The clouds they gather thick again,
When Moſes's rod is lifted up,
But when the rod of pray'r ſinks,
The wreſtling Jacob's on this land
That God wou'd hear their humble groans,
And ſave this land from ruin.
From this time forward we do 〈◊〉
He loſes men where'er he goes,
The water turned from his courſe,
It now and then may hurt a man,
By Howe's long march the Jerſey's thro',
The moſt that he can glory,
Is now and then he robs a whig,
And now and then a tory.
Brave Waſhington he now does feel
For him to take his turn.
By this time Howe does plainly ſee
The hook is in his noſe;
He turns his face and turns about,
He looſes men on the retreat,
And all the way he ſows the ground
Now he flies to the water ſide,
It ſeems this Howe is not a duck,
Nor yet is he an owl;
He is a very ravenous bird,
He does not ramble very far,
Nor does he leap far in the deep,
And now poor Howe muſt taſte the gal • ,
For a long time does little elſe
At length he rouſes up again,
Reſolves that he will try once more
And now I hear he's found his way
And there he lies all couped up,
To leave him there till further news,
For to go on to write and read
Now the firſt news I hear from him.
With many ha • dſhips and fatigues,
And with ſome loſs of men,
Th •• come and make a ſtand.
And qui •• ly there as I do hear,
No, do • bting they ſhould ſtand a fag
And afterw •• d • to n •• i • e us gain,
For what to day we loſt.
Our Gen'ral • s heart is fill'd with fear
This is a d •• k and gloomy day,
Our hearts are fill'd with fear,
Sometimes the darkeſt time of night,
Is juſt before the dawning light,
Oft in the ſummer at theſe hours,
We can't behold the pleaſant ſhowers,
Juſt ſuch the caſe as it concerns
Great threat'ning aſpects it may wear,
God's face ſeems cover'd with a veil.
We cannot ſee the myſt'ry of
This wheel am • dſt a wheel.
But when his counſels come to light
We ſee the plan was wiſe;
Theſe wings that ſeem'd miſterious things,
We ſee are full of eyes.
But who can fathom theſe great deeps,
I find I'm qui • kly l • ſt▪
Oh! may I truſt God, mercy ſtill,
Tho' • h my hopes ſeem croſs'd▪
T •• on •••• ga is gave up,
O God that has rejected us,
O gi • e us help for now we ſee,
Vain is the help of man.
Burgoyne, a proud and wicked wretch,
It ſeems he had Goliah's heart,
Where pride is rooted in the heart,
He tells his men the Americans
They cannot bear the powder ſcent,
I hear him boaſt a while,
That he to Albany ſhould go,
To ev,ry man a maid or two,
That they ſhould be his whore;
To cut and wound, to kill and ſcalp,
Methinks I hear this wicked wretch
He little thought that fatal day
Would bring him ſo much ſorrow.
There's not a promiſe of to-morrow
Whether we live to ſee the day,
Or If we do, much leſs can ſee
Many no doubt, while big with hope
Are quick put down, and ſent into
A fatal ball has ſeized them,
Inſtead of joy and triumph ſongs,
Inſtead of this, I ſay they've bid
And how their ſouls do fair to day,
Their bodies ſerve no other uſe,
Now they lie in the duſt,
But teach vain man he ſhould not in
Perhaps their ſouls they have gone down,
Good had it been for theſe poor men,
Had they but been ſo wiſe,
To learn'd thoſe great important things
That are hid from their eyes.
And Oh! that we who living be,
Might lay theſe things to mind,
That ſo we may in the laſt day,
But ſtay my muſe, go back and trace
For I do hear he is upon
Methinks I ſee him marching on,
Methinks I ſee that fire and cloud
Give light and vigour to our troops,
And now the captain of God's hoſts
He leads th' Egyptians in the ſeas,
Methinks I hear poor Burgoyne ſay
Burgoyne was not like old Baalam,
That could for ſee his fate;
But like a bird catch'd in a ſnare,
To fly is quite too late.
The muſke is crack about his ear • ,
To dread the ſmell of powder.
While many of his men were ſlain,
He muſt a hide the conſequence,
Fools that will never hear advice,
And now poor Burgoyne plainly ſeen
His noſe is out of joint;
There's nothing left for him to do,
But to give up the point.
And now poor Burgoyne muſt lay down
And cringe and bow, the Yankees to,
He'll want the money he has ſpent,
For ſcalping his own men and ours,
Now let him for the future learn
May Britain ſee it is not they.
In vain unjuſt and wicked laws
If that the God of heav'n and earth
And if God's word is ſuch a thing,
O who is like to thee;
The ſhield of thy ſalvation's ſtrong.
This woman cloathed with the ſun,
God gave to her too eagles wings,
And here I humbly truſt ſhe ſhall,
For two whole times and one half time,
This lovely vine God bro't from far.
He cauſed it deep root to take,
And it has fill'd the land.
The dragon ſaw himſelf eaſt out,
I humbly pray this woman may
Still put her truſt in God;
Until the earth opens its mouth,
Altho' ſhe is in trouble now,
I truſt God will deliver her,
That God is in the midſt of her,
And God will riſe up • or her help,
This woman is weak in herſelf,
The • ragon h •• gr •• t enemy,
But why hath • he not been devour▪

Su ••• y be •• ul •
〈◊〉 mighty God
He does he • ſt •• l de • end.
